Each broker's desk touches another on either side as well as directly ahead. It looks like one very long cafeteria style table with  brokers sitting across from and next to each other.  Ther are close to twenty brokers sitting at each table.  On th tables are only two items, phones and index cards.  A  secretary is at the head of each table.  They answer inco calls. Look, this is off the record, but I  spoke to the controller this morning.   He assured me that they will be  reporting better than expected third  quarter earnings next month. (soothing) Right.  See I'm telling you, just sit  tight, everything's fine.  It's type  two buying power.  You're golden.  Call  me in a month from now when you're  rich.  Bye.

If you want them off the phone so bad,  why don't you just hang up?  You have  to excite them about things.   You want them to beg for a broker on  that first call.

I  let you know when you screw up.  Did  you think I was going to pat you on the  back for this casino idea?  Tell you  what an entrepreneur you are?

God, if I  ever asked my father to meet me for a  cup of coffee to talk about my screw-up  he probably he probably would have  laughed.  We didn't have nice little  chats about why I was a bad boy.   Whether I was just calling out for  attention or not.  I got smacked and  then I didn't do it again.  Much  simpler.

dialogues.text: (mutters) Well that really worked great on me,  Dad.

dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.text: She reaches under the desk and pulls out a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Here.  Fill this out.  I'd say have a  seat, but that doesn't look like it's  going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth doesn't have a clue that she is trying to make  conversation with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, when's this shit gettin' started?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie doesn't even look up from her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you.  I'm just not answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sighs as if she's done talking, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open your mouth again and I'll  personally guarantee you never get a  job here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the doors of the trading room opens.  Seth catches glimpse of several brokers crouched down, playing dice ne the far window of the trading room.  The door closes in S MOTION as Seth cranes to get every possible view. Out walks JIM YOUNG.  Jim is a team leader at JT Marlin. is dressed to the T.  He looks like someone not to be fuc with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright guys, come this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room used mostly for interviewing and on the rare  occasion a meeting is needed with someone outside the fir Jim walks in to find Marc sitting at the head of the tabl He laughs to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but that's my seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared) Oh man, I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marc JUMPS to another seat.  He is chided by one of his  friends, the same kid who was having words with Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking dumb-ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can get the fuck out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified) What?  What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me, don't look at me,  just pick your ass up out of that  Italian leather chair and get the fuck  out of this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and leaves without saying another word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We expect everyone here to treat their  co-workers with a certain level of  respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the room is silent and staring at Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calm) Now before I get started I have a  question.  Has anyone here passed the  series seven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hand goes up.  It's one of the few kids who wears a g suit and wasn't too worried looking in the waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a series seven license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you, now you can get out too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we don't hire brokers.  We  train new ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim waits for him to leave the room and then calmly  continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the deal.  I am not here to  waste your time and I can only hope  you're not here to waste mine.  So I'm  gonna keep this short.  You become an  employee of this firm and you will make  your first million within three years. (pauses) Okay?  Let me repeat that.  You will  make a million dollars within three  years of your first day of employment  at JT Marlin.  Everybody got that?   There is no question as to whether you  will be a millionaire working at this  firm, the question is how many times  over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every kid in the room besides Seth is completely starry e at this point.  Some mouths even hang open.  Seth is exci too, but is smarter than the rest... he doesn't show it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm joking.  I am not joking.   I am a millionaire.  It's a weird thing  to hear, right?  I'll tell you, it's a  weird thing to sa.  I'm a fucking  millionaire.  Now guess how old I am?   Twenty-seven.  You know what that makes  me here?  A fucking senior citizen.   This firm is entirely comprised of  people your age, not mine.  Lucky for  me, I am very fucking good at my job or  I'd be out of one.  You guys are the  new blood.  You're gonna go home with  the kesef.  You're the future Big- Swinging-Dicks of this firm.  Now you  all look money hungry and that's good.   Anybody who says money is the root of  all evil, doesn't have it!  Money can't  buy happiness?  Look at the fucking  smile on my face.  Ear to ear, baby.   You wanna hear details?  I drive a  Ferrari 355 cabriolet. (throws keys on desk) I have a ridiculous house on the South  Fork.  I've got every toy you can  imagine.  And best of all, kids, I am  liquid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim takes a pause here and circles the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now that you know what's possible,  let me tell you what's required.  You  are required to work your ass off.  We  want winners, not pikers.  A piker is  someone who walks at the bell.  A piker  asks how much vacation time he gets in  the first year.  See, people work here  to become filthy rich.  No other  reason.  That's it.  You want vacation  time?  Go teach third grade public  school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim pours himself a glass of water from a carafe and drin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your first six months at the firm are  as a trainee... you make one hundred  and fifty dollars a week.  After you're  done training, you take the Series  Seven test.  When you pass, you become  a junior broker and you'll be opening  accounts for your team leader.  After  you open forty accounts you begin  working for yourself and then... sky's  the limit.  Now a word about being a  trainee.  The other brokers, your  parents, whoever: they're gonna give  you shit about it.  And it's true, a  hundred and fifty a week is not a lot  of money, but pay no mind.  You need to  learn the business and this is the time  to do it.  Once you pass the Series  Seven none of it will matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friends are shit.  You're gonna  tell them you made twenty-five thousand  last month and they're not going to  believe you.  Fuck them!  Your parents  don't like the life you lead?  Fuck you  Mom and Dad!  As a trainee you will be  building a foundation for yourself.   Think of it as the foundation to a  building.  Right?  Gotta build the  foundation before you can put up your  skyscraper.  You know what I built? (takes out a model) The fucking twin towers.  Now go home  and think about whether this is for  you.  If you decide it isn't, nothing  to be embarrassed about.  It's not for  everyone.   But if you really want it, then give me  a call on Monday and we'll talk.  Just  don't waste my time.  Alright.  That's  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim walks out of the room leaving the door open behind hi No one has moved from their seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot of Seth walking in the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth walks in.  From the look on his face alone, you can it's his first day of work.  He walks past Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Seth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at her for a long moment.  Her beauty is hittin him for the first time.  No idea what her name is though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorr...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all smiles) It's okay.  I never told you my name.   Besides, you looked pretty frazzled the  other day.  I'd be surprised if you'd  remembered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) No shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth laughs.  Likes her already.  She watches him leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 8:00 and the trading room is already packed.  Seth s at his new desk with a box of cards in front of him. Greg drops down in a seat next to him.  He picks up the b of cards and starts right in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the D&B cards.  Dunn and  Bradstreet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg checks his paper as he continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're the company that supply us with  our leads.  Every one of these cards is  an opportunity.  These are good leads.   People on these cards buy stock.  Your  job is to call them and get them  interested in the firm.  You're not  actually selling stock yet, but you're  selling the dream.  Get 'em wet and  tell them that in a month from now a  senior broker will call them back with  one idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are these people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Average client's forty-five years old,  from the Midwest, two hundred and fifty  thousand dollar annual income, three  million net.  Has a local broker, but  loves a New York guy who sounds good on  the phone.  The card's not gonna tell  you any of that.  Only says their name,  address and occupation.  You gotta feel  them out. (picks up card) Here.  Peter Davis, Vice President of  Parks Telecommunications.  Guy's  probably a whale.  See what he's  playing with.  Truth is it doesn't  matter these days.  With the DOW where  it is now, everyone wants a piece of  the market.  I can close anyone at any  time anywhere in the country.  Just  give me a phone number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN FEINER, the compliance officer, walks out of Michael office.  He looks at Seth as he walks by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg, I have John Duncklee on line  three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not here.  After you qualify the  guy you send him a press packet.  It's  all really easy and it'll get you  feeling comfortable on the phone, which  is key.  This entire business revolves  around the phone.  A good broker makes  over seven hundred calls a day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) What's the phone bill like here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This month was approaching four hundred  thousand.  Now listen to me.  Even  though you're not actually selling  stock yet, I want you to remember the  coda we have here. Did you see  Glengarry Glenross?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then, you remember ABC?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always be closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  Always -- Be -- Closing.   That's the attitude you need.  Always  be closing Seth.  Telling's not  selling.  Now there's two rules you  need to know as a trainee.  The rest  will come later.  Number one, we do not  pitch the bitch here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't sell stock to women.  I don't  care who it is, we don't do it.  I'm  serious.  Nancy Sinatra calls, you tell  her you're sorry.  They're a constant  pain in the ass and never worth the  trouble.   They will call you every fucking day  asking you why the stock is dropping.   And God forbid the stock should go up  you'll hear from them every fifteen  minutes. (mocking) Is it a good time to sell?  It's simply  not worth the time or effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, don't pitch the bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second rule.  Don't write wood.  A lot  of trainee are so anxious to get off  the phone they just steamroll the guy  into getting the press pack so they can  hang up.  Then I call in a month and  say, Hi, you spoke to a junior  associate of mine last month.  The  guy's like, Yeah, I'm not interested.   Bye.  That's a shitty lead.  It's  fucking wood.  The info we send is  bullshit.  The important part of the  call is telling them you have that one  great idea, and that a broker is going  to call them back in a month.  This  shows that we don't just fire a million  recos a day.  We tell them we have six  or seven great ideas a year!  They  don't want to think you're pitching  them something you read in the journal  this morning.  Get it?  No wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got it.  Chill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even start with that shit.  I'm  just telling you what your place is and  what I expect of you.  I'm making your  job easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not the Greg that Seth remembers from the casino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Well what happens if they want  to buy stock right then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, now we're talking.  You should  go into every call thinking just that.   If they want a recommendation, you put  the guy on hold, you stand up, and yell  "RECO" at the top of your lungs.  The  first senior broker to get to the phone  gets the sale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth smiles broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth walks up the path toward Greg's house.  It's a beaut The door is open and Seth slowly lets himself in.  He pas through the living room which as no furniture -- just  cardboard boxes waiting to be unpacked. In the den there are 15 guys from the firm sitting on the floor.  They're eating pizza and drinking beer.  A huge T sits against a wall, the only thing in the room besides t pizza. They are watching the movie "Wall Street".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth!  What's up, man?  Thought you  weren't gonna make it.  Sit down, grab  a slice, have a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at TV) Shut-up, shut the fuck up, Gecko's  coming.  Alright my turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors to Gordon Gecko's office open and Greg begins. following is intercut with scenes from the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's goin' on?  I'm lookin'  at two hundred shares, pal.  I wanna  know if we're part of it.  We better be  or I'm gonna come down and eat your  lunch for you.  Back in two, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richie picks it right up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Jeff.  Look, I loved it at  forty, it's an insult at fifty.  Their  analysts?  They don't know preferred  stock from livestock.  Alright, we wait  till it hits south, then we, we raise  the sperm count on the deal.  Get back  at ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHRIS VARICK picks it up from there.  He's also a team  leader; but has his shit together more tightly than the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the kid.  Calls me fifty-nine  days in a row, wants to be a player.   Oughta be a picture of you in the  dictionary under persistence, kid.   Yeah, now listen, Jerry.  I'm lookin'  for negative control.  No more than  thirty, thirty-five percent.  Just  enough to block anybody else's merger  plans and find out from the inside if  the books are cooked.  Looks as good on  paper and we're in the kill zone, pal.   We'll lock and load.  Lunch? Oh you  gotta be kidding.  Lunch is for wimps.   Okay, Fidel, I'll talk at ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the room says this line in unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Mr. Gecko.  Bud Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you say.  Nice to meet you.  Hope  you're intelligent.  Where'd you get  these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a connection at the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's on your mind, Kimosabi?  Why  am I listening to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound fades down as we see Seth looking around the ro All the money in the world and no one to share it with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie walks in looking beat.  She's just come from work. The apartment is small and modestly furnished.  Working  class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie heads back toward the bedroom.  She walks in to fi her mother in bed coughing.  She does not look well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie gets her mother's medication ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me make some tea.  You sound really  congested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie leaves for the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth is on the phone with his mother.  There is a monitor showing the tables downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, Mom, I'm not a broker yet.   I'm a trainee.  I still need to pass my  series seven test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please, you're a stock broker.  You  wear a suit to work every day, don't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?  What are we arguing about then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing great, Seth.  You're  working your way up from the bottom.   That's never easy.  I'm very proud of  you.  And I told you father about  things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's very happy.  Shocked, but happy.   He's been waiting for you to call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well why doesn't he just call me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One miracle at a time, okay sweetie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth is on the phone trying to make things happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... (looking at card) ...Mr. Mathews please.  Seth Davis.   From JT Marlin.  No, he doesn't know  me.  Yes it's concerning investments.   Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth hangs up the phone and stares at it for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering to himself) Fucking bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dials another number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tech stocks are down today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Warren Buffet, you trying to e  cute?  Make the fucking calls!  You're  not a fund manager!  How's it going  there, Seth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth shrugs his shoulders.  Greg comes over.  The phone i ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Howard Young please.  It's Seth  Davis from JT Marlin.  No, he's not  expecting my call.  No thanks, I'll  call him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, first of all there are going to  be a lot of those regardless of how  good you are.  But you happen to suck  dick.  I have this friend who runs this  other firm.  He gives out this book to  all his trainees.  The Rebuttal Book.   Looks like a fil-o-fax.  Has those  index tabs but they don't say A to B to  G to H, they say things like Wife won't  let me, I'm not in the market now, Call  me back, Send me a prospectus.   Has a rebuttal for any excuse.  That's  all the shit you're gonna have to learn  later.  For now you only have to  remember one thing.  You can be whoever  you want on the phone.  So say what you  have to.  Use a different name if you  want.  Tell them you're a vice- president here.  Just get them on the  line.  That's the first step.  It's the  hardest part sometimes, but just get  the cocksucker on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.  How can I do shit  like that?  Isn't there a compliance  offer here?  Isn't it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Illegal?  No, Seth.  Everyone does that  shit.  Even on Wall Street.  And John  over there, he works for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg points to John who is at a desk in the back of the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a fucking chimp.  The only  compliance work he's doing is making  sure my lunch is still hot when it gets  here.  He's only here because the SEC  requires it.  He might have the easiest  fucking job in the entire world.  Look  at him I think he's actually  masturbating right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Fed-Ex package is brought over by Debbie.  She's got a of them in her hands.  She smiles at Seth as she drops th package on Greg's desk.  Greg sees this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad news.  Stay the fuck away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chris walks over.  Debbie continues to hand out packages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit.  You slut.  You made the  call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling wide) I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth sees Debbie picking up packages as well.  One broker seen angrily stuffing cash into a Fed-Ex envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you went big too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg opens the package and removes a good $20,000 in cash Seth's attention is snapped back to Greg and the package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' A.  Only bookie in New York  that delivers Federal Express.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth and his whole family are having dinner in celebratio Seth's new job.  Marty looks about as happy as pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when are you taking the test?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the training program's over.   They really want you to get a good idea  of how things work before you take the  series seven.  It's a great system.   I'm really learning a lot.  They're  very thorough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna be rich, Seth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God willing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta ask you: how come I've never  heard of this firm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question makes Seth nervous.  Familiar territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're a small firm, Dad.  There's a  million others just like it that you've  never heard of either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess what I'm asking is why you  didn't try and go straight to Goldman  Sachs or a company of that stature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty, why are you starting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calm) It's okay, Mom.  The reason, Dad, is  that the larger houses don't hire kids  straight out of college unless you went  to an Ivy League school or you want to  do cash-flow analysis for the next  fifteen years.  They want you to work  outside their firm for a couple of  years to get a sense of the   marketplace.  That's why almost all  brokers start in small firms like JT  Marlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mother) See, that wasn't so bad.  He answered  the question.  This is good stuff,  Seth.  Good stuff.  So how does it feel  to have a real job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It feels real good, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth looks elated.  There's a long content pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you have to do now is close the  casino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty!  We talked about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth looks at his watch.  He realizes he's late for  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to run, but I'm late to meet a  friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses his Mom and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seth walks into a dimly lit bar in downtown Manhattan.  I a class joint.  He searches the room until he sees Debbie sitting at a table in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big smile) Hey Seth.  Go get yourself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've already had a couple of drinks by now and are pre loosened up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who do you live with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean is the black girl here  taking care of her grandma because her  momma's a crack-head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, exactly.  I thought it was smack,  though.  You know you have got to get a  hold of that edge.  It's kind of sharp  sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed laugh) I know, it's true.  I just got so much  shit at JT.  Sometimes I have to get  into that mode just to fend them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why are you there?  It doesn't seem  like the ideal working environment for  a black woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it isn't.  But tell me, how many  secretaries you know make eighty  thousand a year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could always go back to school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) You pompous ass.  What makes you think  I want to?  College isn't for everyone.   It's not like every black girl dreams  of being a marine-biologist her whole  life. (dramatic) If only she could get out of the  ghetto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you don't have to tell me.  I  dropped out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  Now that's a surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mocking) You know it isn't for everyone.  It's  not like every Jewish boy wants to be a  CPA if only he could make Wharton's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie laughs hard and they settle into intimate eye cont Debbie leans toward Seth who pulls away, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa.  I don't even know what synagogue  you belong to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

But you  could be doing the real thing at a real  trading house.  Instead you're here.   You don't need to be making it this  way.  At a chop-shop.

dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.text: To bending the rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're with JP Morgan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah right.  And I'm a black Negro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know JT.  It's a fucking chop-shop.   Named your firm so it sounds like ours.

dialogues.text: Sounds terrible.

dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.text: And your Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: And me into yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I have so many great ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'm ten years old.  I just got  this new bike.  A red Mongoose.  You  know, BMX.  So I'm skidding out in this  puddle -- Starsky & Hutch style.  My  foot slips, and the pedal spins around  hard enough to break my leg.  Real bad  too.  But I don't fall off the bike.  I  keep coasting down this hill.  So  finally I get scared and I jump off.   Fell right behind a parked car.  Laid  there for half an hour.  Finally, I  hear my father screaming my name from  up the block.  I was so happy that he  was coming to get me.  He comes around  the car and sees me lying there.   There's blood everywhere and the bone  is sticking out straight through my  skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I looked up at him, and for the first  time in my life I saw how much he loved  me.  He was frozen.  It hurt him to see  me in that much pain.  So he leans  down... and slaps me across the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Maybe he was mad at me  for making him that helpless, or it was  the only thing he could think of.  I  don't really care anymore.  What I  remember now is the look on his face  when he first saw me.  That's all I  remember.  That's what I miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie leans over and kisses him deeply.

That's  fair, right?

Anyway, I'm getting ahead of  myself.  And you're real busy over  there.  Why don't I send you out the  info you requested about the firm and a  senior broker will call you next month  with that one idea.

Another broker JUMPS onto the table  separating him from Seth and clambers over it.  Chris put the steam and gets there first.  The other broker runs  straight into Seth, unable to stop. Chris regains his composure wiping the smile off his face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

H KNEELS quickly, coming down on his stomach.  The man's fa raises off the floor in response and Richie ATTACKS his h He stops as suddenly as he started, stand up, and spits o him.  The man is completely unconscious.  Only Seth carri the expression of genuine shock.  The others have seen th before. Richie goes back in and closes the door.

There is a  minimum level of aesthetic  professionalism that we have here.  In  a couple of months you'll be able to  outfit your whole closet, but for now  just get something to hold you over.   There's an important phrase that we use  here and I think it's time you all  learned it.  "Act as if".  Do you  understand what that means?  Act as if  you are the fucking president of this  firm.  Act as if you have a nine inch  cock.  Act as if.  To do this properly  you need to at least look the part.  So  go get dressed.  Secondly, it's time to  get your Series Seven books.  No need  to get nervous.  If you study you'll  pass.  Then you begin trading as an SEC  licensed broker.  Then you're a fucking  millionaire.  It's that simple.  I need  three hundred from each of you for the  books which will be returned if and  when you pass the exam.  And I'll need  that tomorrow.
